node.plaintext:
Rock Fort‚Ä¶After 4 months of intense development, we are proud to announce the
fresh new release of Traefik: 1.4, codename roquefort
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roquefort].

This release is quite big: we merged 250
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/pulls?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Apr%20milestone%3A1.4%20is%3Amerged] 
pull requests from more than 60 contributors ! Huge thanks goes to all of you
who helped on this new version üòò.

The full changelog can be found here
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/releases/tag/v1.4.0] but here are some
new features we want to highlight:

Custom Headers & Security
Our awesome Daniel Tomcej [https://github.com/dtomcej] did some hard work on
headers. We now have a way to customize headers:

> Custom headers can be configured through the frontends, to add headers to either
requests or responses that match the frontend‚Äôs rules. This allows for setting
headers such as X-Script-Name to be added to the request, or custom headers to
be added to the response.
If that was not enough, Daniel added security options on headers:

> Security related headers (HSTS headers, SSL redirection, Browser XSS filter,
etc) can be added and configured per frontend in a similar manner to the custom
headers above. This functionality allows for some easy security features to
quickly be set.
Multi arch
Thanks to Ludovic Fernandez [https://github.com/ldez], we now provide
[https://github.com/docker-library/official-images/blob/master/library/traefik] 
the official Docker image on multiple architectures: amd64, arm64v8, arm32v6.
The best part is that as of mid-September, Docker supports transparent
multi-arch on official images. This allows to use docker run traefik 
transparently either on a amd64 or a arm64v8 Docker daemon. We plan to add a
Windows based official image in the future.

Authentication Forward
As a first step to a generic authentication mechanism
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/issues/593], Daniel Rampelt
[https://github.com/drampelt] followed by Ludovic Fernandez
[https://github.com/ldez], added a way to forward authentication to a delegate
server. Have a look at both [https://github.com/containous/traefik/pull/1972] 
PRs [https://github.com/containous/traefik/pull/2132] to get more details on
this.

Proxy Protocol
Traefik is often used behind another load-balancer like an ELB
[https://aws.amazon.com/elasticloadbalancing]. In this case, Traefik now
supports Proxy Protocol, that allows to keep client information between the
chain of proxies. Have a look at the documentation [https://docs.traefik.io/] to
learn how to enable and configure safely this feature.

Custom Error Pages
Ben Parli [https://github.com/bparli] did some great job on adding custom error
pages support into Traefik. But instead of rendering html pages, we decided to
delegate this task to a backend server. You can now configure Traefik to get
error pages from another server, using this syntax:

[frontends]
  [frontends.website]
  backend = "website"
  [frontends.website.errors]
    [frontends.website.errors.network]
    status = ["500-599"]
    backend = "error"
    query = "/{status}.html"
  [frontends.website.routes.website]
  rule = "Host: website.mydomain.com"

[backends]
  [backends.website]
    [backends.website.servers.website]
    url = "https://1.2.3.4"
  [backends.error]
    [backends.error.servers.error]
    url = "http://2.3.4.5"

In this example, if you hit a 502 error, Traefik will ask to the backend server 
http://2.3.4.5 for the page 502.html.

Datadog, Statd metrics export
Alex Antonov [https://github.com/aantono] completed the existing Prometheus
metrics export with two famous monitoring services: Datadog and Statd. This
allows to easily export internal Traefik metrics to monitoring systems and get 
Grafana dashboards [https://grafana.com/dashboards/2240] of your running
instances.

In A Nutshell
Julien Salleyron [https://github.com/juliens] added GRPC [https://grpc.io/] 
support and made a great user guide [https://docs.traefik.io/] on this.
We now allow to customize cookie names thanks to Ludovic Fernandez
[https://github.com/ldez], see the documentation here
[https://docs.traefik.io/routing/services/].
Drew Wells [https://github.com/drewwells] added the option passTLSCertto forward
TLS Client certificates to the backend.
The documentation website https://docs.traefik.io [https://docs.traefik.io/] has
been revamped by Ludovic Fernandez [https://github.com/ldez].

But that‚Äôs not all, check the whole changelog
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/releases/tag/v1.4.0] to get an idea of
the awesome work that has been done on this release. Lots of bugs have been
fixed and we also have been working on creating
[https://github.com/containous/gallienii] awesome
[https://github.com/containous/lobicornis] bots
[https://github.com/containous/bibikoffi] that
[https://github.com/containous/aloba] do [https://github.com/traefiker] great
things for us.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Grab the latest binary for Linux, Windows, Mac on Github
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/releases/tag/v1.2.0] or get the official
Docker image [https://hub.docker.com/_/traefik/]!

docker pull traefik:v1.4.0 (or 1.4.0, v1.4, 1.4, roquefort)
docker pull traefik:v1.4.0-alpine (or 1.4.0-alpine, v1.4-alpine, 1.4-alpine, roquefort-alpine)

The documentation can be found on https://docs.traefik.io
[https://docs.traefik.io/].


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We are thrilled to welcome Michael Matur [https://github.com/mmatur] who joined 
Containous [/] and Marco Jantke [https://github.com/marco-jantke] who joined the
maintainers team üëã ! We are hiring developers and evangelists:
containo.us/#jobs !

Traefik is still growing fast, we just passed 10k stars
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/stargazers] on Github and 22M downloads!


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We would love to hear your feedback on this new release. Join us on GitHub
[https://github.com/containous/traefik], Twitter
[https://twitter.com/traefikproxy] or on the Community Forum
[https://community.containo.us]!

After 4 months of intense development, we are proud to announce the fresh new release of Traefik: 1.4, codename roquefort.

This release is quite big: we merged 250 pull requests from more than 60 contributors ! Huge thanks goes to all of you who helped on this new version üòò.

The full changelog can be found here but here are some new features we want to highlight:

Custom Headers & Security

Our awesome Daniel Tomcej did some hard work on headers. We now have a way to customize headers:

Custom headers can be configured through the frontends, to add headers to either requests or responses that match the frontend‚Äôs rules. This allows for setting headers such as X-Script-Name to be added to the request, or custom headers to be added to the response.

If that was not enough, Daniel added security options on headers:

Security related headers (HSTS headers, SSL redirection, Browser XSS filter, etc) can be added and configured per frontend in a similar manner to the custom headers above. This functionality allows for some easy security features to quickly be set.

Multi arch

Thanks to Ludovic Fernandez, we now provide the official Docker image on multiple architectures: amd64, arm64v8, arm32v6. The best part is that as of mid-September, Docker supports transparent multi-arch on official images. This allows to use docker run traefik transparently either on a amd64 or a arm64v8 Docker daemon. We plan to add a Windows based official image in the future.

Authentication Forward

As a first step to a generic authentication mechanism, Daniel Rampelt followed by Ludovic Fernandez, added a way to forward authentication to a delegate server. Have a look at both PRs to get more details on this.

Proxy Protocol

Traefik is often used behind another load-balancer like an ELB. In this case, Traefik now supports Proxy Protocol, that allows to keep client information between the chain of proxies. Have a look at the documentation to learn how to enable and configure safely this feature.

Custom Error Pages

Ben Parli did some great job on adding custom error pages support into Traefik. But instead of rendering html pages, we decided to delegate this task to a backend server. You can now configure Traefik to get error pages from another server, using this syntax:

[frontends]
  [frontends.website]
  backend = "website"
  [frontends.website.errors]
    [frontends.website.errors.network]
    status = ["500-599"]
    backend = "error"
    query = "/{status}.html"
  [frontends.website.routes.website]
  rule = "Host: website.mydomain.com"

[backends]
  [backends.website]
    [backends.website.servers.website]
    url = "https://1.2.3.4"
  [backends.error]
    [backends.error.servers.error]
    url = "http://2.3.4.5"

In this example, if you hit a 502 error, Traefik will ask to the backend server http://2.3.4.5 for the page 502.html.

Datadog, Statd metrics export

Alex Antonov completed the existing Prometheus metrics export with two famous monitoring services: Datadog and Statd. This allows to easily export internal Traefik metrics to monitoring systems and get Grafana dashboards of your running instances.

In A Nutshell

Julien Salleyron added GRPC support and made a great user guide on this.
We now allow to customize cookie names thanks to Ludovic Fernandez, see the documentation here.
Drew Wells added the option passTLSCertto forward TLS Client certificates to the backend.
The documentation website https://docs.traefik.io has been revamped by Ludovic Fernandez.

But that‚Äôs not all, check the whole changelog to get an idea of the awesome work that has been done on this release. Lots of bugs have been fixed and we also have been working on creating awesome bots that do great things for us.

Grab the latest binary for Linux, Windows, Mac on Github or get the official Docker image!

docker pull traefik:v1.4.0 (or 1.4.0, v1.4, 1.4, roquefort)
docker pull traefik:v1.4.0-alpine (or 1.4.0-alpine, v1.4-alpine, 1.4-alpine, roquefort-alpine)

The documentation can be found on https://docs.traefik.io.

We are thrilled to welcome Michael Matur who joined Containous and Marco Jantke who joined the maintainers team üëã ! We are hiring developers and evangelists: containo.us/#jobs !

Traefik is still growing fast, we just passed 10k stars on Github and 22M downloads!

We would love to hear your feedback on this new release. Join us on GitHub, Twitter or on the Community Forum!

node.plaintext:
We released Traefik 1.2 only two months ago
[/blog/traefik-1-2-morbier-is-out-8bc304a66ef3/], and we are proud to announce
that the fresh new Traefik 1.3, codename raclette
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raclette] is out!

As Traefik is getting bigger and bigger, we decided to accelerate things and to
release more often. From a 4 months release cycle, you will now have to wait
only 2 months between each release.

The full changelog can be found here
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/releases/tag/v1.3.0] but here are some
new features we want to highlight:

Multiple Rules by Container
Thanks to Florent Benoit [https://github.com/benoitf], Traefik can now manage
multiple rules by container, introducing service labels
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/pull/1257]. You can now easily forward
multiple ports from a same container :) Here are all available labels:

traefik.<service-name>.port
traefik.<service-name>.weight
traefik.<service-name>.protocol
traefik.<service-name>.frontend.backend
traefik.<service-name>.frontend.entryPoints
traefik.<service-name>.frontend.rule
traefik.<service-name>.frontend.passHostHeader
traefik.<service-name>.frontend.priority
traefik.<service-name>.frontend.rule

Amazon DynamoDB support
Tskinn [https://github.com/tskinn] made a great job on integrating
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/pull/1158] Traefik with Amazon DynamoDB
[https://aws.amazon.com/fr/dynamodb/], a flexible NoSQL database service. You
can now push your configuration (frontends and backends) into this database and
Traefik will watch any changes dynamically.

Basic Authentication per Frontend
Another awaited feature, Manuel Laufenberg [https://github.com/santode] added 
basic authentication per frontend
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/pull/1147] configuration (it was only
globally configurable initially). Currently, Docker and Rancher backends are
supported, more will be added in the future!

Dashboard Filter
Ludovic Fernandez [https://github.com/ldez] added a nice little feature
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/pull/1437] in the webui: you now can
filter frontends and backends. When you have a big configuration with many
routes, it‚Äôs really handy to be able to quickly find what you want.

But that‚Äôs not all, check the whole changelog
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/releases/tag/v1.3.0] to get an idea of
the awesome work that has been done on this release. Lots of bugs have been
fixed and we have begun a strong background work on our CI infrastructure and
project quality in general.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Grab the latest binary for Linux, Windows, Mac on Github
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/releases/tag/v1.2.0] or get the official
Docker image [https://hub.docker.com/_/traefik/]!

docker pull traefik:v1.3.0 (or 1.3.0, v1.3, 1.3, raclette)
docker pull traefik:v1.3.0-alpine (or 1.3.0-alpine, v1.3-alpine, 1.3-alpine, raclette-alpine)

The documentation can be found on https://docs.traefik.io
[https://docs.traefik.io/].


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Following our $1M seed
[/blog/containous-raises-1-million-in-seed-round-funding-to-develop-traefik-f8238f47d2c7/]
, 4 new developers joined Containous [/] and are now part of the maintainers
team. We are thrilled to welcome Ludovic Fernandez [https://github.com/ldez], 
Attilio Borello [https://github.com/atbore-phx], Julien Salleyron
[https://github.com/Juliens] and Nicolas Mengin [https://github.com/nmengin] üëã
!

Traefik is still growing fast, we just passed 8k stars
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/stargazers] on Github and 7M downloads!


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We would love to hear your feedback on this new release. Join us on GitHub
[https://github.com/containous/traefik], Twitter
[https://twitter.com/traefikproxy] or on the Community Forum
[https://community.containo.us]!

node.plaintext:
After 4 months of hard work, we are proud to announce a new release of Traefik:
version 1.2.0, codename Morbier [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morbier_cheese].

The full changelog can be found here
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/releases/tag/v1.2.0] but here are some
new features we want to highlight:

Amazon EC2 Container Service
Thanks to Luke Petre [https://github.com/lpetre], Traefik now supports Amazon
EC2 Container Service [https://aws.amazon.com/fr/ecs]. This is a great news for
AWS fans who need more than an ELB/ALB to manage their inbound traffic.

Rancher
Finally, Traefik gets native Rancher support! Thank you Manuel Laufenberg
[https://github.com/santode]! It is now a lot simpler to have a specific
configuration backend right into Traefik.

Prometheus
A lot of people were waiting for it, thanks to Alberto Garcial
[https://github.com/enxebre], native Prometheus support is now real :) This
allows you to export internal metrics to Prometheus using a simple flag 
‚Äîweb.metrics.prometheus. More internal metrics will be added soon!

Netflix Eureka
Eureka [https://github.com/Netflix/eureka] is the service registry taken from
the Netflix OSS stack. Traefik now supports Eureka as a configuration backend
thanks to Julien Salleyron [https://github.com/Juliens]!

Healthchecks
Another long awaited feature, healthchecks are here! Again, thanks to Julien
Salleyron [https://github.com/Juliens]. A health check can be configured in
order to remove a backend from LB rotation as long as it keeps returning HTTP
status codes other than 200 OK.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Grab the latest binary for Linux, Windows, Mac on Github
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/releases/tag/v1.2.0] or get the official
Docker image [https://hub.docker.com/_/traefik/]!

docker pull traefik:v1.2.0
docker pull traefik:morbier
docker pull traefik:v1.2.0-alpine
docker pull traefik:morbier-alpine

The documentation can be found on https://docs.traefik.io
[https://docs.traefik.io/].


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In case you missed it, we just raised $1M
[/blog/containous-raises-1-million-in-seed-round-funding-to-develop-traefik-f8238f47d2c7/] 
:) You can expect a lot of new features in the coming months, as well as 
background work [https://github.com/containous/traefik/issues/1266]. Of course,
all this will be done involving the community as much as possible.

Traefik is still growing fast, we just passed 7k stars on Github
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/stargazers] and 3.5M downloads! The
maintainer team gains 2 more maintainers, Thomas Recloux
[https://github.com/trecloux] & Timo Reimann [https://github.com/timoreimann] 
üëã!


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We would love to hear your feedback on this new release. Join us on GitHub
[https://github.com/containous/traefik], Twitter
[https://twitter.com/traefikproxy] or on the Community Forum
[https://community.containo.us]!

node.meta_description: After 4 months of development, we are proud to announce the second release of Traefik: version 1.1.0, codename camembert.
node.plaintext:
Camembert [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camembert] cheeseAfter 4 months of
development, we are proud to announce the second release of Traefik [/traefik/]:
version 1.1.0, codename camembert [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camembert].

The full changelog is quite huge
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/releases/tag/v1.1.0] but here are some
new features we want to highlight:

Swarm mode support
In v1.12, Docker introduced swarm mode [https://docs.docker.com/engine/swarm/],
for natively managing a cluster of Docker engines. Traefik is now able to
connect to a swarm manager and will discover all services deployed on the swarm.
Thank you diegofernandes [https://github.com/diegofernandes] for your work :)

Constraints
samber [https://github.com/samber] initiated the addition of constraints, that
limits Traefik scope to a smaller number of routes. It allows to easily deploy
multiple instances with specific roles.
Let‚Äôs give an example and add this line to our TOML configurations:

# traefik instance 1
constraints = [‚Äútag==eu-*‚Äù, ‚Äútag==asia-*‚Äù]

# traefik instance 2
constraints = [‚Äútag==us-*‚Äù]

The instance 1 will now route services tagged with eu-* or asia-* (i.e. 
eu-backend, eu-frontend, asia-data‚Ä¶) and the instance 2, services tagged with 
us-*.
You can use Docker labels, Marathon labels or Consul Catalog tags to tag your
services. For example, let‚Äôs deploy a new Docker application and tag it:

docker run -d -l traefik.tags=eu-frontend emilevauge/whoami


This application will be taken into account by traefik instance 1 and ignored by
instance 2.

Mesos backend
PierreLeresteux [https://github.com/PierreLeresteux] & skydjol
[https://github.com/skydjol] made a great pull request adding universal Mesos
support to Traefik. In addition to Marathon
[https://mesosphere.github.io/marathon/], Traefik can now be used with any Mesos
framework (i.e. Chronos, Aurora, custom‚Ä¶). And yeah, the v1.1 codename is 
camembert because of those Normans [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normans] guys!

Why not Saint-Nectaire
[https://github.com/containous/traefik/pull/353#issuecomment-233914436]?Session
affinity
Long awaited [https://github.com/containous/traefik/issues/5#issue-107706542] 
sticky sessions are now supported thanks to owen [https://github.com/owen]! Use
them with caution [https://12factor.net/processes] ;)

Cluster mode (experimental)

node.html:
After 4 months of development, we are proud to announce the second release of Traefik: version 1.1.0, codename camembert.

The full changelog is quite huge but here are some new features we want to highlight:

Swarm mode support

In v1.12, Docker introduced swarm mode, for natively managing a cluster of Docker engines. Traefik is now able to connect to a swarm manager and will discover all services deployed on the swarm. Thank you diegofernandes for your work :)

Constraints

samber initiated the addition of constraints, that limits Traefik scope to a smaller number of routes. It allows to easily deploy multiple instances with specific roles.
Let‚Äôs give an example and add this line to our TOML configurations:

# traefik instance 1
constraints = [‚Äútag==eu-*‚Äù, ‚Äútag==asia-*‚Äù]

# traefik instance 2
constraints = [‚Äútag==us-*‚Äù]

The instance 1 will now route services tagged with eu-* or asia-* (i.e. eu-backend, eu-frontend, asia-data‚Ä¶) and the instance 2, services tagged with us-*.
You can use Docker labels, Marathon labels or Consul Catalog tags to tag your services. For example, let‚Äôs deploy a new Docker application and tag it:

docker run -d -l traefik.tags=eu-frontend emilevauge/whoami

This application will be taken into account by traefik instance 1 and ignored by instance 2.

Mesos backend

PierreLeresteux & skydjol made a great pull request adding universal Mesos support to Traefik. In addition to Marathon, Traefik can now be used with any Mesos framework (i.e. Chronos, Aurora, custom‚Ä¶). And yeah, the v1.1 codename is camembert because of those Normans guys!

Session affinity

Long awaited sticky sessions are now supported thanks to owen! Use them with caution ;)

Cluster mode (experimental)

Traefik now has a cluster mode, which allows to deploy multiple instances sharing the same configuration. To do that without copying the same configuration file on each instance, Traefik uses a distributed Key-Value store (Etcd, Consul supported). What is great with cluster mode is that it works with Let‚Äôs Encrypt, using the Key-Value database to store the TLS certificates. Cluster mode is available in this release as an experimental feature.

Official Alpine image

In addition to the official ‚Äúfrom scratch‚Äù Docker image, there is now an official Alpine image tagged v1.1.0-alpine, camembert-alpine. This can be useful to get a shell access to a Traefik container for debugging purpose.

Experimental builds

For those who want to test bleeding edge features, we introduced experimental builds. Each time a pull request is merged into master branch, a docker image will be pushed at:

containous/traefik:experimental

A specific PR image will also be pushed at:

containous/traefik:pr-#

Grab the latest binary for Linux, Windows, Mac on Github or get the official Docker image!

docker pull traefik:v1.1.0
docker pull traefik:v1.1.0-alpine
docker pull traefik:camembert
docker pull traefik:camembert-alpine

The documentation can be found on http://docs.traefik.io.

Finally, we are very pleased to announce that dtomcej and SantoDE just joined the maintainers team. Welcome on board!

We would love to hear your feedback on this new release. Join us on GitHub, Twitter or on the Community Forum!

node.meta_description: There are many ways to provide a configuration to a program. Some use Command Line Interfaces, others use configuration files...
node.plaintext:
There are many ways to provide a configuration to a program. Some use Command
Line Interfaces, others use configuration files. Any setting changes can require
a refactor on many lines of code. The configuration loading process have to be
very robust. If not, programs could not work as we expected. Unfortunately 
golang [https://golang.org/] programs are no exception. For instance, adding a
new argument in a CLI requires to create a flag, to parse data, to deal with the
help section, to manage default values and to affect the collected value into
the configuration structure.

Close your eyes and imagine a library able to automatically manage all this
configuration process for you. You can open them because we did it :)


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Fl√¶g
Fl√¶g [https://github.com/containous/flaeg/] is a Go package for building
dynamically a powerful modern Command Line Interface and loading a program
configuration structure from arguments. Go developers don‚Äôt need to worry about
keeping flags and commands updated anymore : it works by itself !

Fl√¶g package was born from the need of Tr√¶fik [/traefik/], the famous reverse
proxy created by Emile Vauge [https://github.com/emilevauge]. It was more and
more difficult to maintain the list of `flags`: parameters passed in argument
which drive the program.

Thanks to Fl√¶g [https://github.com/containous/flaeg/], the maintenance became a
thing of the past. The `flags` are auto generated from the field names of the
configuration structure. To do that, developers just have to add a StructTag
[https://golang.org/pkg/reflect/#StructTag] following the field to create a flag
on it. The helper (i.e. what is displayed with -help argument) is generated from
the key `description` in the StructTag
[https://golang.org/pkg/reflect/#StructTag]

Here an example of a complex configuration with StructTag
[https://golang.org/pkg/reflect/#StructTag] that Fl√¶g can process:

flaegdemo.config.goGitHub Gist: instantly share code, notes, and snippets.
262588213843476Gist
[https://gist.github.com/cocap10/bbd5672a81175e07492c6c9e7b43aba7]Fl√¶g
[https://github.com/containous/flaeg/] is able to load the argument values
‚Äã‚Äãgiven in the configuration structure through reflection
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reflection_(computer_programming)]. The package
supports most of field types, but no collections. Hopefully users can add a
custom parser on specific types as collections or even whole structures.

Let‚Äôs see how simple it is to use Fl√¶g.

First we will create a trivial command which do nothing but print the
configuration:

Golang Configuration Made Easy With Fl√¶g And St√¶rtGolang Configuration Made
Easy
With Fl√¶g And St√¶rt - flaegdemo.cmd.go262588213843476Gist
[https://gist.github.com/cocap10/600d3491c9f005195c3c8bc9234dfc99]Then, we only
have to create a Fl√¶g object and call the function Run :

flaegdemo.use.goGitHub Gist: instantly share code, notes, and snippets.
262588213843476Gist
[https://gist.github.com/cocap10/69620f12c8fad0953269df5edb3bb58d]Let‚Äôs try this
program. We will first call the helper :

flaegdemo.help.shGitHub Gist: instantly share code, notes, and snippets.
262588213843476Gist
[https://gist.github.com/cocap10/b8cb3e8f78d1661eefd0f48f46e38e65]As you can
see, the generated flags match the fields of the configuration structure with
substructures `DatabaseInfo` and `OwnerInfo`. Default values ‚Äã‚Äãcan be defined
directly in the fields of the configuration structure. These fields will be
unchanged if their `flags` are not used in argument.

Then, we can try the program:

flaegdemo.try.shGitHub Gist: instantly share code, notes, and snippets.
262588213843476Gist
[https://gist.github.com/cocap10/090406f9f88d59d89e7dd0f09edcd8eb]Fl√¶g also
handles sub-command, like the ‚Äúversion‚Äù command in the example :

flaegdemo.sub.cmd.goGitHub Gist: instantly share code, notes, and snippets.
262588213843476Gist
[https://gist.github.com/cocap10/2a88cf1605f3d4187c15e129d8b58a1d]
flaegdemo.version.try.shGitHub Gist: instantly share code, notes, and snippets.
262588213843476Gist
[https://gist.github.com/cocap10/5112adbf0f83027dc0fb7e30bd5cea80]To learn much
more about Fl√¶g, please visit the github project page 
https://github.com/containous/flaeg.

Thanks to Fl√¶g, we have a nice solution to load the configuration from the
flags. The maintenance is now way simpler than it used to be, which is
appreciated on open source projects. But how can we manage merging this CLI
configuration with other sources like configuration files ?


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

St√¶rt
The CLI is not the only way to provide configuration to a program. There are
other sources of configuration. For instance, Tr√¶fik can take a configuration
from flags, from a config file and from a distributed Key-Value Store.

We created St√¶rt [https://github.com/containous/staert/] to merge those
configuration sources. So far, only flags (using Fl√¶g
[https://github.com/containous/flaeg/]), TOML config file and Key-Value Stored
[https://github.com/containous/staert#kvstore] configuration are implemented,
but we did the package in such way that it is easy to add other sources.

St√¶rt uses the same Command type
[https://github.com/containous/staert#the-command] as Fl√¶g
[https://github.com/containous/flaeg].

We just have to create some sources
[https://github.com/containous/staert#use-st%C3%A6rt-with-sources] :

staertdemo.create.sources.goGitHub Gist: instantly share code, notes, and
snippets.262588213843476Gist
[https://gist.github.com/cocap10/d8f1742a119e5f0069790f4fbf230d59]Then, we can
create a St√¶rt [https://github.com/containous/staert] object and use it :

staertdemo.use.goGitHub Gist: instantly share code, notes, and snippets.
262588213843476Gist
[https://gist.github.com/cocap10/6742ba6bf48d82b62feae2c6c8f2af4c]St√¶rt will
load the configuration in the row and overwrite it following precedence order :

 * Key-Value Store source
 * Fl√¶g source
 * TOML config file source

Here an example of TOML file :

staertdemo.try.tomlGitHub Gist: instantly share code, notes, and snippets.
262588213843476Gist
[https://gist.github.com/cocap10/6273109426155223099407cd9a2624cc]And there is
the way to store the Key-Value :

staertdemo.kv.mdGitHub Gist: instantly share code, notes, and snippets.
262588213843476Gist
[https://gist.github.com/cocap10/3115098a4c56b4bc13df9cc0182ac556]This was a
simple example of what we can do with St√¶rt.

To conclude, those two packages made us save a lot of time on the Tr√¶fik project
[https://github.com/containous/traefik]. We can now load and merge several
configurations from different sources. Any changes on the configuration
structure are automagically handled.

More features are described on the Github project pages, please visit :

 * Fl√¶g: https://github.com/containous/flaeg/
 * St√¶rt: https://github.com/containous/staert/

After ten months of development, we are proud to announce the first stable
release of Traefik [/traefik/]: version 1.0.0, codename reblochon.

> Tr√¶fik is a modern HTTP reverse proxy and load balancer made to deploy
microservices with ease. It supports several backends (Docker
[https://www.docker.com/], Swarm [https://docs.docker.com/swarm], Mesos/Marathon
[https://mesosphere.github.io/marathon/], Kubernetes [http://kubernetes.io/],
